1110705121766313984.text: I don't particularly mind that the judge cursed at me. The guy is an animal but I’ve got thick skin. What I intensely dislike is that the judge made a veiled threat against my client. That makes me angry because it compromises my ability to represent her properly. Its unfair. 8/9

1110704476845953024.text: The Judge ends the conference abruptly. It’s just me, the other attorney, and the judge. I allow my adversary to exit the room before me. Judge starts to walk past me but he stops. He looks me right in the eye & he hisses, “Counsel you do *not* know who you are f*cking with.” 7/9

1110704228434104321.text: Finally, he calls the case for conference. My argument does not change in chambers. I want a hearing on the legal fees. Judge *really* wants me to drop it. He gets plaintiff to increase the settlement by 8k. Now he *demands* I take it. I say no, we want a hearing on the fees. 6/9

1110704075245535232.text: The Judge congratulates plaintiff’s counsel for procuring a high settlement. That is completely obnoxious to the defense attorney, who is standing right there. But then he turns to the defense attorney & says “you got an amazing deal also.” Oh okay. Now I see. It's like that. 5/9

1110703928205864960.text: I make my argument and we’re still not resolved so Judge wants to conference the case which means going into chambers with no stenographer for off-the-record discussions. While waiting for the case conference, he calls another case that has settled. Now he’s a picture of joy. 4/9

1110703790582317057.text: He takes a break and then comes back on the bench. He apologizes, but also he puts words in her mouth. He says something like “you've never seen me that way before right?” And of course she says “Never, Judge” because that’s the way this game works. She has to come back here. 3/9

1110703429368844289.text: It is my first time in front of this judge. He calls the case. There’s a bit of back-and-forth between me & opposing counsel. Suddenly the judge is apoplectic. He’s screaming at my adversary -- veins are popping out of his neck. Apparently he thought she was talking over him? 2/9

1110703268966092801.text: I have a case where I am helping a widow who lost her husband in a tragic accident. It is a pro bono case which means I do it for free. 1097568298353524736.text: Takeaways: Consider religious freedom and the societal trade-off that it requires. Be tolerant of anti-vaxxers, especially when their objections are religious. Also, try to avoid political divisions when discussing important matters of public health. 26/26 https://tinyurl.com/y6yjgwcb

1097568021839822850.text: Takeaways: Prioritize public education and continued research. Consider low-hanging policy fruit like ending philosophical exemptions. Keep religious exemptions and do not limit them to people in existing churches. Instead think about smarter ways to police the exemptions. 25/26

1097567523376193537.text: Group 1 and Group 3 risks are the primary reasons anti-vaxxers opt out. It is useful to realize that many anti-vaxxers are not rigidly anti-science. Many now accept that vaccines do not cause autism. So research and public education make a lot of sense from any perspective. 24/25

1097567356182777857.text: Group 3 doesnt include autism & other disproved links. However with any medicine it is virtually impossible to affirmatively disprove links to everything. There are also limits to what can be studied longitudinally. That leaves the possibility of some unknown vaccine risks. 23/25

1097567106726592514.text: Group 2 dangers include various ailments and conditions that render some vaccines more dangerous for specific people. Important: One cannot claim a medical exemption based on Group 1 risk. A doctor must state that you have a specific “medically recognized” contraindication. 22/25pic.twitter.com/k1lvinpFXW

1097566760650326017.text: Group 1 dangers of the MMR vaccine include common risks: sore arm from the shot, fever, mild rash, temporary joint pain & stiffness. There are also very rare (and more serious) MMR risks that include: febrile seizures, thrombocytopenic purpura & encephalitis/brain swelling. 21/25

1097566613560311809.text: This brings us to a discussion of vaccine dangers. One must distinguish between real versus imagined & known versus unknown. I put the dangers into 3 groups: (1) known risks that appear on the label, (2) patient-specific contraindications & (3) some number of unknown risks. 20/25

1097566128228974592.text: Laws recognize that there are real risks to vaccines. All 50 states allow medical exemptions. In 1986, Congress passed the National Childhood Vaccine Injury Act. It gave immunity to manufacturers & set up a fund to compensate people hurt by vaccines. 19/25 https://tinyurl.com/y8luzt5k

1097565939393011712.text: Perhaps the best way to understand Ray, Lukumi, Masterpiece & Smith? The winners were the drug laws, a religious bigot, and an executioner. The losers were gay men wanting to marry, Native Americans trying to worship, and a condemned man seeking his last rites. Enough said. 18/25

1097565776356302848.text: After Ray, SCOTUS seems capable of nearly anything. Could a Christian Scientist win a free-exercise challenge to mandatory vaccination in MS because the state doesnt allow religious exemption? There is zero chance under existing precedent, but does that really tell us much? 17/25

1097565573876277248.text: Could NY try to end abuse of its religious exemption by returning to the original statute requiring “bona fide membership” in a “recognized” church? That seemed doubtful until Ray, where SCOTUS allowed an inmate to be executed under a law that gave preference to Christians. 16/25

1097565408134160384.text: SCOTUS seemed to retreat from Smith when it reversed Lukumi & then decided Masterpiece, but the nature of its rulings (coupled with the changing composition of the Court) make it difficult to predict how it might answer the 1A questions that relate to mandatory vaccination. 15/25

1097565258506518529.text: The point is that RFRA, and the state RFRA laws that followed Boerne, reflected a broad political consensus favoring special protection for religion. The ubiquity of religious exemptions in state vaccination laws further reflected the consensus. Has opinion on this changed? 14/25

1097564583076741125.text: A huge backlash followed Smith. In 1993 Congress “overruled” Smith by passing the Religious Freedom Restoration Act. The Senate was 97-3! RFRA was later struck down in Boerne because Congress cant overrule SCOTUS on matters of constitutional law but that isnt the key point. 13/25

1097564349848342529.text: Justice Scalia cited cases supporting his belief that the 1A doesnt require religious exemption from mandatory vaccination laws (Cude) & school attendance laws (Yoder). He also pointed to a law preventing animal cruelty (Lukumi) that was upheld despite religious objections. 12/25

1097564175105253377.text: In 1990, Justice Scalia opined that “free exercise” of religion ought not confer to adherents any exemption from “neutral” laws. In Smith, he justified Oregon’s denial of unemployment benefits to Native Americans solely because they had used peyote as a religious sacrament. 11/25

1097564064555909120.text: Protecting religious freedom has costs: society affords the same benefit to the Baker as it does to the Anti-vaxxer. Mostly, that is the right to do things that society considers wrong and otherwise illegal -- like discrimination, refusing vaccination, and animal sacrifice. 10/25

1097563914332717059.text: This helps us understand why Masterpiece turned on questions of religion. Among jurists there would be almost no dispute that the baker who refused a cake to a gay couple did violate Colorado’s anti-discrimination law *but for* the fact that that his objection was religious. 9/25

1097563709143158784.text: Delineating between religious & non-religious can be dicey. Judging sincerity of religious belief is even dicier but without such inquiry, religious exemptions become de facto philosophical exemptions. This bill would scrap religious exemptions in NY. 8/25https://politi.co/2H1vj7j

1097562764577513473.text: This is critical because in NY there is no philosophical exemption. Parents can claim a religious exemption without belonging to a recognized church. (They write a letter.) This opens the door to people claiming religious exemption even when their objection is truly secular. 7/25

1097562576890810369.text: 47 states allow religious exemption for Jehovah’s Witnesses, Christian Scientists, etc. NY’s law exempted “bona fide members" of "recognized" churches but a federal court struck it down as violative of the 1A “no establishment” clause for favoring some religions over others. 6/25

1097562043425738752.text: Religious exemption from mandatory vaccination laws mean that children are not excluded from school based on their family religion. This is a good thing. Unvaccinated kids can be excluded in the event of an outbreak. This is happening right now in NY. 5/25https://tinyurl.com/y4s3ynoe

1097561549504462849.text: Philosophical exemptions (PEs) allow parents to opt out based on *non* religious belief (read: so basically anything). Most states do not allow this. Those that do should consider ending it. This study confirmed my priors: PEs lower vaccination rates. 4/25 https://tinyurl.com/y2db6gmr

1097561179310997505.text: The laws say if parents dont immunize their kids, those kids cannot attend school. If kids are not in school (or being home-schooled & tested), then the parents can be charged with neglect. There are critical pockets of failure but the system mostly works as it was intended. 3/25

1097561063334297600.text: Vaccination laws are part of the powers traditionally reserved to states. There are 50 statutes (plus case law) which vary somewhat. One key feature of state vaccination laws is that they do *not* require people to get shots. Nor do they force people to vaccinate their kids. 2/25

1097560899643162627.text: Thread on vaccination laws, exemptions, issues of religious freedom, medical risks, and anti-vax. The last thing we need is a public shouting match. This tweet concerned me. 1094142234595938304.text: A "note" is a debt instrument. A "mortgage" is a security instrument. 1072889971101589505.text: Plea agreement is now being discussed. SDNY and MC remain at impasse. Scope of plea agmt is narrow. SDNY thinks MC hasn't told them everything. (This plea agreement therefore leaves MC open to future charges if other bad acts are discovered.)
